title: Screening (low-bias)
intro: Rate how often each statement fits your real life. Higher scores mean you can deprioritize the related dominant function check. Use Skip if you truly can’t judge.

items.text: I often miss small steps in detailed procedures even when others think they matter.
examples: I get reminded for forgetting minor steps (closing, labeling, cleaning, formatting).
I prefer “good enough” over following a long checklist perfectly.
I only do the full procedure when someone is watching or it’s strictly required.

items.text: I frequently ignore the standard method and do it my own way instead.
examples: I dislike copying a template exactly; I change it to fit my style.
I try shortcuts even if they’re not the official method.
I get bored doing the same proven method repeatedly.

items.text: When I’m free, I chase something new rather than repeating a familiar comfort routine.
examples: On a free day, I want a new place/food/activity, not the same safe choice.
Repeating the same hobby feels dull quickly.
I feel restless if life becomes repetitive for too long.

items.text: Long-term direction talk (5–10 years) usually feels boring or hard to care about.
examples: When people discuss far-future plans, I mentally check out.
I focus on what’s next week/month rather than a long narrative.
I feel fine without a “life mission” or clear calling.

items.text: I rarely think in symbolism/hidden meaning; I prefer literal, concrete talk.
examples: I dislike reading ‘between the lines’; I prefer direct statements.
Abstract meaning-talk feels vague or unhelpful.
I’d rather discuss practical details than big metaphors.

items.text: If I have full freedom, I follow my mood instead of setting a future goal for the day.
examples: A free day becomes entertainment/relaxing first, goal-setting later (or never).
I don’t naturally structure my day around a long-horizon objective.
I prefer flexible wandering over a single planned purpose.

items.text: Loud, crowded, high-stimulation environments physically drain me quickly.
examples: I need quiet breaks at parties/events to recover.
Too much noise/light/activity makes me feel overloaded.
I prefer calm spaces over high-energy environments.

items.text: I’m usually the one who slows people down when they want to do risky rule-breaking.
examples: I often say “don’t do that, it’ll cause trouble.”
I avoid risky stunts even if others find it fun.
I feel uncomfortable when plans depend on bold impulsive action.

items.text: I often overthink implications and hidden meaning instead of taking things at face value.
examples: I ask myself “what did they really mean?” a lot.
I replay conversations to interpret motives.
I worry about consequences more than enjoying the moment.

items.text: Open-ended tasks make me feel blank; I prefer a clear topic and instructions.
examples: Too much freedom feels stressful rather than exciting.
I work faster when I’m given a specific target.
Brainstorming feels tiring unless someone else leads it.

items.text: I feel safest when my schedule is planned; too many options stress me out.
examples: I prefer someone deciding the plan so I can follow it.
Sudden changes throw me off more than they energize me.
I like routine because it reduces uncertainty.

items.text: When facing something new, I focus on risks more than curiosity.
examples: My first thought is often “what could go wrong?”
I avoid new environments until I feel fully prepared.
I prefer proven paths over experimenting.

items.text: I often comply with illogical rules just to avoid the hassle of arguing.
examples: I think “whatever, I’ll just do it” even if it makes no sense.
I rarely challenge contradictions unless it directly hurts me.
I dislike debates and would rather keep peace.

items.text: I struggle to learn complex theory without someone giving me a structure first.
examples: I need a guide/outline before I can understand.
Self-study feels confusing without step-by-step help.
I rely on teachers/tutorials to organize the logic.

items.text: In arguments, I side with whoever feels nicer rather than who is technically correct.
examples: I care more about harmony than logical precision.
I avoid criticizing flawed reasoning if it may upset someone.
I choose the socially safe side when I’m unsure.

items.text: I can accept doing things I dislike fairly easily as long as life stays stable.
examples: I can tolerate an unwanted path if it avoids conflict.
I rarely feel intense inner resistance like “I can’t betray myself.”
I prioritize stability over personal preference.

items.text: I often say “anything is fine” because I don’t have strong preferences.
examples: Choosing food/activities is easy because I don’t care much.
I follow the group without feeling bothered.
I rarely feel “I MUST choose this because it fits me.”

items.text: I treat strong emotions as unreliable and try to shut them down quickly.
examples: I tell myself “stop being emotional, it’s useless.”
I justify feelings logically before accepting them.
I don’t trust emotions to guide decisions.

items.text: In groups, I rarely take charge; I wait for someone else to lead.
examples: I prefer being assigned tasks rather than assigning others.
Leading feels stressful or unnecessary to me.
I avoid setting deadlines or pushing people.

items.text: I delay decisions because I overthink the perfect answer.
examples: I rewrite/revise too much and finish late.
I second-guess myself and struggle to conclude.
I’d rather keep options open than commit.

items.text: I stay quiet about problems to avoid upsetting people, even if it hurts results.
examples: I avoid blunt feedback even when it’s necessary.
I let inefficient plans continue to keep peace.
I soften facts so others won’t feel bad.

items.text: People have called me rude/insensitive because I miss social-emotional cues.
examples: I say things bluntly and regret it later.
I don’t notice mood shifts until someone tells me.
I’m confused why certain words “hurt” people.

items.text: When I have a problem, I handle it alone rather than seeking emotional support.
examples: I don’t like sharing feelings; I solve it privately.
I avoid asking for comfort even when stressed.
I feel awkward opening up.

items.text: I sometimes refuse to help if it feels like a waste of my time, even if it disappoints others.
examples: I weigh cost/benefit before doing favors.
I don’t feel obligated to be ‘nice’ if it’s inefficient.
I prioritize my needs without much guilt.
